author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Expansion of Democracy Is What Republican Elites Fear Most
description: There are minorities whose interests are harmed by majority rule. But they are not minorities as we tend to think of them; they are elites.
content: Conventional wisdom says that the rule of the majority is in unavoidable tension with the rights of the minority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Before Jan. 6, Aide Warned Secret Service of Security Risk to Pence
description: New details flesh out how the pressure campaign by Donald J. Trump and his allies to block certification of the 2020 election left the vice president’s staff fearing for his safety.
content: The day before a mob of President Donald J. Trump’s supporters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Vice President Mike Pence’s chief of staff called Mr. Pence’s lead Secret Service agent to his West Wing office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: In a Blistering Final Spell-Off, Harini Logan, 14, Wins the National Bee
description: An eighth grader from San Antonio, Harini returned to the finals with a reinstatement, kept pace in a drawn-out duel with Vikram Raju, and spelled 21 words correctly in the final 90 seconds.
content: They both knew what was coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Special Olympics lifts a vaccine mandate at its Games in Orlando after Florida threatens a fine.
description: Florida health officials told Special Olympics that the vaccine requirement violated state law.
content: Special Olympics lifted its coronavirus vaccine requirement for athletes and staff members at its U.S.A. Games in Orlando, Fla., this weekend after Florida threatened a $27.5 million fine over the mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Sophie Freud, Critic of Her Grandfather’s Gospel, Dies at 97
description: Sigmund Freud’s last surviving grandchild, she fled the Nazis in Vienna, became a professor in America and argued that psychoanalysis was a “narcissistic indulgence.”
content: Sophie Freud, who fled the Nazi onslaught in Europe and escaped to the United States, where, as a professor and psychiatric social worker, she challenged the therapeutic foundation of her grandfather Sigmund’s theories of psychoanalysis, died on Friday at her home in Lincoln, Mass. The last surviving grandchild of Sigmund Freud, she was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: At Least 4 Dead After Train Derails in Germany
description: Rescue crews from Austria were helping on the scene in southern Germany, where more than a dozen people were taken to a hospital with serious injuries.
content: At least four people were killed and dozens of passengers were injured when their train partly derailed near the Alpine resort town of Garmisch-Partenkirchen in southern Germany, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: From the Bones of Victims, a Doctor Unearths a Drug War’s True Toll
description: Raquel Fortun, one of only two forensic pathologists in the Philippines, is using her skills to show how other doctors falsely claimed some victims of the country’s drug war had died natural deaths.
content: QUEZON CITY, Philippines — Standing in a university classroom surrounded by six skeletons lying on wooden tables, Raquel Fortun held up the broken skull of a man who was slain during President Rodrigo Duterte’s drug war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Dodgers Offer a Belated Embrace to a Player Shunned for Being Gay
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 3, 2022.
content: “He could jump out of a stadium. With his vertical leap, he could have been one of Santa’s reindeer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina
title: Thousands Swept Up as Kremlin Clamps Down on War Criticism
description: The arrests are a stark gauge of how the Kremlin has intensified repression of critics. At least 50 people now face years-long prison sentences.
content: Vladimir Efimov, a local politician on the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia’s Far East, was charged with “discrediting the army” and ordered to pay a $500 fine three times in recent months over antiwar images that he displayed on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Far From the Fighting, a Tennessee Deli Nurtures Its Ties to Ukraine
description: A couple opened Potchke, a pop-up in Knoxville, to showcase their love of the war-ravaged country and its cooking.
content: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — When Russia invaded Ukraine, Laurence Faber and Emily Williams’s first reaction was to cook borscht. Ukrainian flags had yet to spread across the American lawn-scape, and Potchke, the couple’s Ukrainian-inspired deli, had yet to open in this eastern Tennessee city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Overlooked No More: Maureen Colquhoun, Pathbreaking Politician Waylaid by Bias
description: Colquhoun campaigned for women’s rights in Britain’s male-dominated Parliament. But her political career came to an end when she was outed as a lesbian.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Farmers’ Markets Are Bountiful This Time of Year in California
description: The state has some 700 markets featuring some of the world’s best produce — but it took legislative changes in the 1970s to help them flourish.
content: Fed up with bad news, I went the other day to the farmers’ market, one of my favorite places in Sacramento. Sweet cherries were in season, for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: What’s Got Economists Rooting for a Slowdown
description: With nearly twice as many open jobs as available workers and rising inflation, many economists and policymakers say a slowdown is just what the economy needs.
content: This morning, the Labor Department is reporting how many jobs employers added in May. Yesterday, data from payroll operator ADP signaled a significant drop-off in hiring. But the official employment report showed that companies added 390,000 jobs to their payrolls last month, the 17th straight monthly gain. That will disappoint some economists who believe a slowdown now could be a good thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Yeah Yeahs Yeahs’ Apocalyptic March, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Kyshona, the Mountain Goats, Maggie Rogers and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Who’da Thunk It!
description: Robyn Weintraub, true to form, delivers an impeccable Friday puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s a Robyn Weintraub Friday™! OK, I guess that term is technically not yet trademarked, but Ms. Weintraub should consider pursuing the rights to the phrase. After all, this is her 26th Friday puzzle (out of a total of 41 New York Times Crosswords) — she’s really found her niche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Ukraine says Russia controls 20 percent of its territory.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russian forces had seized 20 percent of Ukraine’s territory as the war nears its 100th day. He said that Russia had expanded its control of Ukrainian territory from an area roughly the size of the Netherlands before the invasion to an area now greater than the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg combined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Class Sizes Set to Shrink in New York City Schools, but at What Cost?
description: A bill approved by state lawmakers to shrink New York City class sizes would cost millions, and its passage reignited a longstanding debate about whether the move would help students as intended.
content: Mayor Eric Adams won a partial victory in the State Legislature this week, when lawmakers extended mayoral control over New York City  schools for another two years, half of what the mayor had sought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: A financier suspected in a nearly $2 billion Danish tax fraud is arrested.
description: Prosecutors believe Sanjay Shah was behind an elaborate scheme to cheat the Danish tax system.
content: The London-born financier suspected of masterminding an elaborate scheme to bilk the Danish tax system of $1.9 billion has been arrested by the police in Dubai for possible extradition to Denmark, authorities in Copenhagen said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: David McCormick Concedes to Dr. Oz in the G.O.P. Primary for Senate in Pennsylvania
description: With a statewide recount still underway, Mr. McCormick stepped aside to Dr. Mehmet Oz, who is set to be the Republican nominee in one of this year’s most pivotal midterm races.
content: David McCormick, a former hedge fund executive, conceded the exceedingly close race for the Republican nomination for Senate in Pennsylvania on Friday to Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity television physician, with a statewide recount underway and no official race call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ivry
title: How a Track Coach Spends Her Sundays
description: Jean Bell, the founder of Jeuness Track Club, an all-girls running team, stays active on the sidelines.
content: During the week, Jean Bell serves as an administrative law judge for the New York State Workers Compensation Board. But on the weekends, you will find her cheering along the sidelines of track meets all over the tristate area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Rob Szypko, Will Reid, Eric Krupke, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Dan Powell
title: The Cost of Haiti’s Freedom
description: Two centuries ago, Haitians revolted against their French masters and declared independence. But this freedom came at a price.
content: In 1791, enslaved Haitians did the seemingly impossible. They ousted their French masters and created the first free Black nation in the Americas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Luke Broadwater
title: Navarro Indicted as Justice Dept. Opts Not to Charge Meadows and Scavino
description: The House had recommended contempt charges against all three Trump White House aides over their stonewalling of its Jan. 6 inquiry.
content: A federal grand jury on Friday indicted Peter Navarro, a White House adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, for failing to comply with a subpoena from the House committee investigating the Capitol attack, even as the Justice Department declined to charge Mark Meadows and Dan Scavino Jr., two other top officials who have also refused to cooperate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Nick Madigan
title: Tropical Weather Threatens Florida With Heavy Rain and Floods
description: The system could become Tropical Storm Alex, the first storm of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season.
content: KEY WEST, Fla. — Three days into hurricane season and South Floridians were already being warned to rehearse a familiar drill: clear storm drains, get sand bags if your neighborhood tends to flood and watch out for standing water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: 21 Americans Infected With Monkeypox, C.D.C. Reports
description: As the number of cases outside Africa approaches 800, governments are scrambling for a limited pool of vaccines and treatments with unclear effectiveness.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has identified 21 monkeypox cases in 11 states, and the numbers are expected to rise, officials reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: An indoor mask mandate returns to Alameda County, Calif., home to Oakland.
description: Officials cited growing hospitalizations in reimposing the policy.
content: Alameda County, the San Francisco Bay Area’s second-most populous county, reinstated on Friday a mask mandate in most indoor spaces, which it had dropped in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: When Freedom Is Only the Beginning
description: Refugees who’d spent years in detention had a lot of questions about their new lives in Australia. Some were easier to answer than others.
content: During the weeks I spent with refugees who had just been released after more than eight years in Australia’s immigration detention regime, I got asked a lot of questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Connolly
title: Don’t Think Too Hard About These TikTok Videos
description: The point of @favetiktoks420 isn’t to find deeper meaning in trends but to luxuriate in their strangeness.
content: Even if you’ve spent no time on TikTok, you probably have some idea of what’s happening there. Headlines about dance challenges, aesthetics (WitchTok! Cottagecore! Coastal grandmother!) and viral audio clips have proliferated over the last few years, each trend treated as a way to decipher the habits of Gen Z.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Erin Griffith
title: What Sheryl Sandberg’s Exit Reveals About Women’s Progress in Tech
description: Silicon Valley is losing one of its most visible, outspoken and powerful women. Any gains have been incremental at best.
content: When Sheryl Sandberg said this week that she was resigning as chief operating officer of Meta, she also reflected on her legacy as a woman in tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Worthen
title: 400 Years Ago, They Would Be Witches. Today, They Can Be Your Coach.
description: As more and more Americans call themselves spiritual but not religious, spiritual coaches give us a glimpse of the allure and the hazards of 21st-century D.I.Y. religion.
content: Erica Carrico suspects that if she’d lived 400 years ago, she would have been accused of witchcraft. “Women who were healers, who were connected to the moon cycle and nature, they were considered witches,” she told me. “I love following the moon. I feel divinely guided by my intuition. I’ve done the new moon and the full moon ceremony. I’ve practiced with crystals quite a bit and sage, sweat lodges. I’ve done so many things, just trying to find my way, what feels right.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Review: Ballet Is Spectacle in ‘Like Water for Chocolate’
description: Christopher Wheeldon’s full-length work for the Royal Ballet succeeds best when not meeting the demands of storytelling.
content: LONDON — Twelve white-robed, veiled brides stand motionless onstage as the curtain rises on Christopher Wheeldon’s new full-length “Like Water for Chocolate,” for the Royal Ballet. Slowly the women back away, then turn. Now, they are dressed in black, a row of crones, who sit and begin to knit as the action begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Kids With Long Covid
description: There are still more questions than answers
content: Experts estimate that long Covid — a cluster of lingering symptoms including fatigue, headaches, brain fog, racing heart and stomach issues — may affect about one in five adults. Studies suggest that long Covid is rarer in children, but they can develop it too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: How Low Must Inflation Go?
description: The peculiarity of the 2 percent target.
content: As I pointed out in my latest column, the politics of inflation are dominated by concerns about gasoline and food prices — precisely the prices over which policymakers in general, and the president in particular, have the least influence. Economists, by contrast, usually focus on measures that try to get at underlying inflation, excluding highly volatile stuff like, well, energy and food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
description: As the war in Ukraine marked its 100th day, Africa was urgently seeking relief from the disruptions of critical supplies of grain and other staple foods. Some of the world’s poorest countries face alarming levels of hunger and starvation and the United Nations has warned that Russia’s naval blockade of Ukraine could lead to famines around the world.
content: As the war in Ukraine marked its 100th day, Africa was urgently seeking relief from the disruptions of critical supplies of grain and other staple foods. Some of the world’s poorest countries face alarming levels of hunger and starvation and the United Nations has warned that Russia’s naval blockade of Ukraine could lead to famines around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Conservative’s View on Democrats’ Biggest Weakness
description: Reihan Salam explains how Republicans can build a more diverse party.
content: “There is definitely a contest for the future of the center right,” says Reihan Salam, the president of the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think tank. In his telling, one side in this contest is “deeply pessimistic about the prospect of a diversifying America, explicitly anti-urban and increasingly willing to embrace redistribution and centralized power,” more so than conservatism before Donald Trump. This populist right has received a lot of attention since Trump’s election, and we’ve done other shows to try to understand it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: His Second Try at a Good First Impression Did the Trick
description: Though Michael Quinn’s bad joke didn’t land with Lea Richard-Nagle when they met a party, she didn’t write him off. Days later, the two had a memorable first date at the Guggenheim Museum.
content: Michael Sague Quinn failed pretty spectacularly when he tried to make Lea Beatrice Richard-Nagle laugh at a private party at the Boom Boom Room in Manhattan in February 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Again and Again and Again
description: The Tulsa mass shooting wasn’t as deadly as some feared. Instead, it was yet another American tragedy.
content: In the early hours after the shooting at a Tulsa medical center on Wednesday, the details were murky. Soon, it became clear that the death toll there was not going to be as nearly as high as the tolls from the recent shootings in Uvalde and Buffalo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: North Carolina TV stations pull an attack ad against Cheri Beasley, a Democrat running for Senate.
description: Ms. Beasley is running against Representative Ted Budd, a Republican, in a race for an open seat that is important in determining control of the Senate.
content: Television stations in North Carolina made the unusual decision on Friday to take down an attack ad against Cheri Beasley, a Democratic Senate candidate, after complaints that the ad falsely accused Ms. Beasley of freeing a man convicted on charges of possessing lewd images of children when she served as chief justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Julian E. Barnes
title: Gina Haspel Observed Waterboarding at C.I.A. Black Site, Psychologist Testifies
description: The testimony emerged in pretrial hearings in the Cole bombing case at Guantánamo Bay, where the war court is wrestling with the legacy of torture after 9/11.
content: WASHINGTON — During Gina Haspel’s confirmation hearing to become director of the C.I.A. in 2018, Senator Dianne Feinstein asked her if she had overseen the interrogations of a Saudi prisoner, Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, which included the use of a waterboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Nadelson
title: The New York Butcher Offering Smoked Meats and Support for Ukraine
description: The East Village Meat Market has prepared kielbasa, stuffed cabbage and more comforts of Eastern Europe for over 50 years.
content: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Driving Iceland’s Overlooked North
description: For those seeking an alternative to the popular Golden Circle, the Diamond Circle winds through volcanic landscapes featuring powerful waterfalls, misty vistas and sulfurous pools.
content: The landscape surrounding the Myvatn Nature Baths seethes. Steam drifts from fissures in volcanic seams and belches from lava tubes. Bubbling mud is ringed in chemical greens and oranges. The baths themselves — broad, chest-deep pools surrounded by porous lava rock — smell of the sulfur that’s said to relax and restore bathers. From a hut with a sliding service window on one edge of the pool, a woolen-clad bartender dispenses tap Gull beer to bathers who hold their pints above the warm water while sinking to their chins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Weight Loss Tied to a Dramatic Drop in Cancer Risk, New Study Shows
description: Researchers found that subjects who underwent weight loss surgery also showed a sharp decrease in their likelihood of dying from cancer.
content: A large new study found that people who lost significant amounts of weight through bariatric surgery gained a striking benefit: Their likelihood of developing cancer fell sharply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: He’s a Star for the Digital Age. Some Think His Belt Is Paper.
description: After using YouTube to raise his profile, Devin Haney was promoted from interim champion without a title fight. A bout for the undisputed lightweight belt is his chance to remove the doubt among some of his contemporaries.
content: LAS VEGAS — In early May, a month before a scheduled fight for the undisputed lightweight championship in Melbourne, Australia, Devin Haney stood mid-ring at the Top Rank Gym here, trading punches and trash talk with a contender named Kenneth Sims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Boston Celtics Stun Golden State in N.B.A. Finals Game 1
description: Golden State led by double digits entering the fourth quarter, but the Celtics came roaring back to win.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — After a long and eventful road to the N.B.A. finals, Golden State was grateful for a full week to rest and recover before facing the Boston Celtics in Game 1 on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: A Bird’s-Eye View of Central Park and Beyond, for $70.5 Million
description: One of New York City’s priciest closings this year took place at 432 Park Avenue, amid residents’ complaints of building defects.
content: A full-floor penthouse near the top of the supertall tower at 432 Park Avenue, on Midtown Manhattan’s Billionaires’ Row, has sold for $70.5 million, after nearly two years on the market and a sizable price chop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Stellantis to Pay $300 Million to End an Emissions Case
description: The carmaker’s U.S. division, formerly Fiat Chrysler, was accused of trying to evade federal standards. It pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge.
content: The U.S. division of the carmaker Stellantis has agreed to plead guilty in federal court in Detroit to a conspiracy charge and to pay a $300 million penalty to resolve an investigation of the company’s attempts to evade diesel emission standards, the Justice Department said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Cade Metz
title: Tesla to Cut 10% of Salaried Staff, Musk Tells Employees
description: The electric carmaker has been growing fast in recent years, but Elon Musk, its chief executive, appears to be concerned about a weakening economy.
content: Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, plans to cut 10 percent of the electric carmaker’s salaried work force, he told staff in an email on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith, Lydia DePillis and Jeanna Smialek
title: Hiring Remains Strong Even as Fed Tries to Cool Economy
description: The Labor Department reported 390,000 new jobs in May, as policymakers try to ease inflation without inducing a recession.
content: American employers extended an impressive run of hiring in May, even as policymakers took steps to cool the economy in an effort to ease high inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Mark Rylance on ‘Jerusalem’ and the Golf Comedy ‘Phantom of the Open’
description: The acclaimed British actor explains the links between his tour de force stage turn and a recent string of subdued screen roles.
content: One Tuesday afternoon last month, Mark Rylance was sitting in his London home, his face and body bearing the accouterments of Johnny (Rooster) Byron, the rowdy onetime daredevil he has been playing in a revival of Jez Butterworth’s “Jerusalem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elysa Gardner
title: Broadway’s Beloved Basement Club, Feinstein’s/54 Below, Turns 10
description: The venue beneath what was once Studio 54 will pick up a Tony Award for excellence in the theater as it marks its anniversary with a pair of concerts.
content: On June 5, 2012, shortly after noon, a bevy of cabaret and theater artists and insiders gathered in a space beneath what had been the storied West 54th Street nightclub Studio 54. The occasion was a dress rehearsal for a show that evening that would open a new venue called, reasonably enough, 54 Below. Patti LuPone was the featured act, with other Broadway and nightlife luminaries, including Ben Vereen and Justin Vivian Bond, slated to appear soon afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Full Transcript: Biden’s Speech on Guns
description: As the nation grieves for the victims of several recent mass shootings, the president called for a ban on assault weapons and new “red flag” laws.
content: President Biden gave an address at the White House on Thursday calling for Congress to pass several gun control measures after a spate of recent mass shootings. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: An Artist Comfortable in Any Medium, Even Lithium
description: Lydia Ourahmane creates sprawling installations that challenge geopolitical borders.
content: Name: Lydia Ourahmane
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: The chief executive of Amazon’s consumer business is leaving.
description: Dave Clark, who was also the architect of the company’s sprawling warehouse operations, said he would depart after 23 years.
content: Dave Clark, the chief executive of Amazon’s consumer business, who was the architect of its massive warehouse operations, announced on Friday that he would leave the company after 23 years. He did not say what he would do next, and the company did not immediately name a successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Celtics Strike First in Finals by Working Late
description: A fourth-quarter rally turned the tide in Game 1 against Golden State, but Boston isn’t celebrating anything just yet.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The Boston Celtics’ reaction to winning Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night was a marked contrast from the joyous celebration they had held after winning Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals earlier in the week. Instead of chest bumps at midcourt after the final buzzer, the Celtics walked stoically off the court on Thursday, each player stone-faced, some engrossed in conversations with coaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Serge F. Kovaleski, Eduardo Medina and Mike Baker
title: No Radio, Old Tactics: How the Police Response in Uvalde Broke Down
description: The commander at the scene arrived without a police radio, and decided in the first minutes on an approach that would delay a confrontation.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Two minutes after a gunman burst through an unlocked door at Robb Elementary School and began shooting inside a pair of connected classrooms, Pete Arredondo arrived outside, one of the first police officers to reach the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: ‘This Pride Month I’m Partnering With’ Memes Are Coming Out Strong
description: Online, the L.G.B.T.Q. community is having fun with the corporate sponsorship of Pride month and the influencers who take part in those campaigns.
content: June 1 marks the beginning of Pride month, when parades pop up in cities around the world and rainbows start appearing in ads for liquor, banks, makeup and big-box department stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aamina Ahmad
title: Concussed, Kidnapped, Cursed: Women on the Run
description: The protagonists of three new novels flee disasters both natural and man-made.
content: Allison Brody has left her abusive boyfriend, a Los Angeles movie producer, to start over in North Carolina. After she spends everything she has on a beach house — including the “small inheritance” from her father’s recent death and money from the sale of a horror movie script — a life of simple comforts seems within reach. But after a week and a half of swimming and turkey sandwiches, a Category 3 hurricane leaves her home strewn across the beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Why Adjustable-Rate Mortgages Are Still Risky
description: The loans’ interest rates are initially low. But while some of their worst features are gone, their rates may still rise considerably over time.
content: Remember adjustable-rate mortgages?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: As Targeted Killings Spike, Hindus Are Desperate to Flee Kashmir
description: Decades after militant violence forced many of them out of the disputed region, hundreds of families have left in another exodus.
content: ANANTNAG, Kashmir — As hundreds of Hindu families fled the Kashmir region in recent weeks amid a spike in targeted militant attacks, Sandeep Raina, a 38-year-old engineer, resigned himself to his worst fear: that he would have to abandon his home once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Steven Erlanger and Michael Levenson
title: 100 Days of War: Death, Destruction and Loss
description: The grinding conflict in Ukraine has rocked the global order, wrought destruction that “defies comprehension” and shows little sign of ending soon.
content: One hundred days ago, before sunrise, Russia launched artillery strikes on Ukraine before sending troops racing toward major cities, beginning a war against a much smaller country and outnumbered military that seemed destined to quickly topple the government in Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Are the Best No-Show Socks?
description: A reader asks for help finding a pair that won’t slip.
content: Socks are one of those often-overlooked wardrobe items that deserve more attention than they get. Given the amount of time we spend on our feet, great socks can improve our quality of life, making walking and other daily activities spent in ballet flats, sneakers and loafers a pleasure. Or at least a relatively pain-free experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Chekhov Two Ways, With a Robot and Baryshnikov Along for the Ride
description: With its production of “The Orchard,” juxtaposing the human and the virtual, the Arlekin Players continue taking creative leaps.
content: When the director Igor Golyak began working on a staging of Chekhov’s “The Cherry Orchard,” he had an idea in mind. “There was a concept,” he said, then interrupted himself. “I’d rather not talk about what it used to be, if that’s OK. The war started, me being from Kyiv and having this affinity for the Russian culture. …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Solís
title: Asked to Adapt a Classic Play, This Writer Rethought Her Life
description: As she sought the truth for her characters on the page, Mara Vélez Meléndez’s real self began to emerge. Now she’s making her Off Broadway debut.
content: In 2018, as part of a masters program in playwriting at Hunter College in Manhattan, Mara Vélez Meléndez was given a life-changing assignment: adapt a classic play. She chose “John Gabriel Borkman,” a rarely revived late Ibsen play about an ambitious banker, and in her reworking, the characters became members of the Financial Oversight and Management Board for Puerto Rico, created in 2016 by the U.S. federal government to resolve the island’s debt crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s latest puzzle contains multitudes.
content: ACROSTIC — Solving an acrostic is always a journey, often one that builds on itself with a mishap here and there, sometimes one that involves a few missed turns. Once in a while I find that even though my solve is successful — I’m making progress on the clues, filling in the passage correctly — the solution turns out to be a surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Samella Lewis, Artist and Activist for Art World Diversity, Dies at 99
description: In addition to painting, she was a historian who pushed for a more inclusive definition of art, in part by founding her own museum devoted to Black artists.
content: Samella Lewis, a Black artist and art historian who did more than just decry the racial blinders of the white art establishment, in part by founding a museum dedicated to promoting Black arts, died on May 27 in Torrance, Calif., near Los Angeles. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Romance Deepened by the Golden Rule
description: Stephanie Insalaco, a bereavement therapist, and Thomas Ciccotta, a lawyer who works with sexual abuse survivors, fell more in love by witnessing the empathy each has shown others.
content: Of all the traits that have attracted Stephanie Nicole Insalaco and Thomas John Ciccotta to one another over the course of their relationship, perhaps none has drawn them closer than how each has treated other people along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuval Levin
title: Why Are We Still Governed by Baby Boomers and the Remarkably Old?
description: Wouldn’t the temperate sins of midlife serve our politics well just now?
content: America’s top political leaders are remarkably old. Our president will turn 80 this year. His predecessor, who is contemplating running again, is about to turn 76. The speaker of the House is 82. The Republican leader in the Senate is 80, and his Democratic counterpart is a comparatively sprightly 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: For 2 Graffiti Artists, New York’s Subway Was Irresistible and Deadly
description: Armed with cans of spray paint, two men traveled from France to seek out the form’s gritty roots in a quest that ended tragically on the tracks.
content: New York City was the playground they had imagined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: In Napa Valley, a Commitment to One Another, and to Showcasing Diversity
description: As an interracial couple, Erika Graves and Brad Cameron felt it was important that their wedding reflect their reality, so they hired a roster of vendors from diverse backgrounds.
content: Erika Graves and Bradley Cameron had been together for roughly six years, and engaged for more than two, by the time they set off on a five-month road trip from Oakland, Calif., to New York and back in April 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Caleb McLaughlin of ‘Stranger Things’ Slays Tennis Balls
description: The Netflix child actor has grown up and is filming a LeBron James biopic.
content: “I’m sweating,” Caleb McLaughlin said, sounding surprised. “I never sweat. I usually get moist. A little damp. I’m sweating!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: For Joel Kim Booster, Making ‘Fire Island’ Was a Real Trip
description: The writer and star of “Fire Island” reflects on making the rare romantic comedy that puts gay Asian American men at its center.
content: Joel Kim Booster had a thought: Why do we even need movie trailers? Sure, they give people a bite-size look at a film they might find intriguing, but couldn’t we just … not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Depp Trial Exposes Risks to Media in Airing #MeToo Accusations
description: Both the women making accusations, and the press when it publishes them, assume the considerable risk that comes with antagonizing the rich, powerful and litigious.
content: Hours after a Virginia jury awarded the actor Johnny Depp more than $10 million in his defamation lawsuit against Amber Heard, his former wife, The Washington Post appended a lengthy editor’s note to the essay where the sordid dispute began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: It’s Salad-for-Dinner Season
description: Yasmin Fahr’s salmon and couscous salad with cucumber-feta dressing is a master class in contrasting textures.
content: I can hardly believe it, but here we are in grill season, beach-picnic season, salad-for-dinner season — summer, my favorite time of year to cook. Some people prefer fall for its crispness; winter for its coziness; spring for its promise of something green. Not me. I am here for summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Before Walking Down the Aisle, Marching With Many Puppets
description: After meeting through a Craigslist personal ad that neither can remember placing, Jonathan Gann and Michael Shankle had their first date at the Million Puppet March in Washington.
content: Jonathan Harris Gann and Michael Dustin Shankle can recall certain facts about their first meeting. It was through a Craigslist personal ad and the ad writer wasn’t seeking a serious relationship. But the identity of the writer is something both said they have forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Gay Bar’ and ‘Afterparties’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: GAY BAR: Why We Went Out, by Jeremy Atherton Lin. (Back Bay, 320 pp., $17.99.) According to our reviewer, Hugh Ryan, Atherton Lin “has a five-octave, Mariah Carey-esque range for discussing gay sex.” He focuses on one gay bar per chapter in this lyrical memoir, jumping from San Francisco to London to Los Angeles, to tell a story about life “flensed down to just the bits that made it past the bouncer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: ‘We Have Not Forgotten Syria’: U.S. Envoy Vows to Protect Refugees
description: After 11 years of war, Syria has become a cautionary example of what can happen in a conflict with no end in sight, like the one that began 100 days ago in Ukraine.
content: HATAY, Turkey — The Alaa Aldin family bakery could have been a casualty of Syria’s civil war. Instead, it has become a symbol of what American officials describe as the resilience of refugees trying to survive a conflict that many fear has been forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: U.K.’s ‘Brightest and Best’ Visa Leaves Out Africa, India and Latin America
description: Under the new program, graduates of top-ranked global colleges can move to Britain for two years, even without a job offer. But critics say the plan nurtures global inequalities.
content: LONDON — When Britain started a program this week offering a two-year visa to graduates from some top global universities, Nikhil Mane, an Indian computer science student at New York University, welcomed the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Pumped-Up Prices
description: “Good thing we’re not going very far.” Eight people, one gas station in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Adams, Hailed on the National Stage, Finds Frustration Closer to Home
description: Mayor Eric Adams faced a bumpy first round in pushing his agenda in Albany, particularly when it came to his education goals.
content: Mayor Eric Adams was supposed to have an easier time in Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Beatrice Rana Plays Tchaikovsky at Human Scale
description: The pianist made her New York Philharmonic debut with the composer’s Piano Concerto No. 1, on a program with Shostakovich.
content: The New York Philharmonic’s season isn’t quite over. There are a couple of chamber concerts coming up, and, next Friday, a one-off at Carnegie Hall, as well as the traditional parks programs in mid-June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Zelensky tells U.S. mayors to end their sister-city ties with Russia.
description: The Ukrainian president said the relationships allow Moscow to say ‘it is not isolated.’
content: RENO, Nev. — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called out several American cities for having sister cities in Russia during a video address to the United States Conference of Mayors meeting on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Jill Cowan
title: The Mall Mogul and Former Republican Who Could Lead Los Angeles
description: Rick Caruso, a billionaire front-runner in Tuesday’s primary election for Los Angeles mayor, has built his campaign on a law-and-order message.
content: LOS ANGELES — At the Grove, the luxury shopping center he created in the middle of Los Angeles, Rick Caruso is treated like the mayor of the mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Very Specific Risk
description: Preconceptions about Liverpool supporters and policing decisions that didn’t prioritize their safety led to the chaos at the Champions League final. That’s dangerous for every fan.
content: It can be hard, at times like these, to know exactly who to believe. On one side, there are the thousands of witness accounts, the contemporaneous reports from much of the world’s news media, the countless videos and an apparently bottomless reserve of high resolution photographs, all telling one story about last Saturday’s Champions League final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: When Age Is Nothing but a Favorite Number
description: Chelsea Cimilluca connected with Lauren Levin on Hinge after setting her age preference on the dating app to 39 years old, Ms. Levin’s age at the time and Ms. Cimilluca’s favorite number.
content: Just 20 minutes into their first date in January 2020, Lauren Elizabeth Levin and Chelsea Veronica Cimilluca, who had previously connected on the dating app Hinge, realized that they had already met in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: When Egg-in-a-Hole Meets Savory French Toast
description: Roasted asparagus and toasts dipped in a Parmesan-infused custard turn a childhood favorite into so much more.
content: Hybrid dishes run the gamut from the sublime to the ridiculous. For every Cronut and brookie bringing delight, there’s a ramen burger or pizza taco just waiting to make you shake your head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: With ‘Neptune Frost,’ How to Make an Afrofuturist Sci-Fi Musical
description: What does technological progress look like to those exploited to achieve it? The co-directors Saul Williams and Anisia Uzeyman discuss their unusual film.
content: The unconventional sci-fi musical “Neptune Frost” (in theaters), from the co-directors and partners Saul Williams, a seasoned musician and actor from New York, and Anisia Uzeyman, a Rwandan actress and filmmaker; interrogates the notion of technological progress from the vantage point of those living in the places exploited to achieve it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: She Was the Strongest Knight
description: A performance of “Camelot” marked her recovery from anorexia. It also began the end of her romantic relationship.
content: Abby Comey, a finalist in Modern Love’s college essay contest, was near death from anorexia when she met Sarah. It took Sarah’s steady love, professional help, Ms. Comey’s efforts and her role as Sir Lancelot in the play “Camelot” to restore her health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: My Family Got Covid. So Why Did We Test Negative?
description: The key to this household mystery may lie in our vaccination status, experts say.
content: As a science journalist, I’ve read dozens of research papers about Covid-19, and I’ve interviewed so many virologists, infectious disease physicians and immunologists over the past two years that I’ve lost count. But nothing prepared me for what happened after my 7-year-old daughter tested positive for Covid-19 nearly two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: New York Lawmakers Move to Counter Rightward Shift Elsewhere
description: The Democrats who control the State Legislature voted to restrict gun use, bolster voting rights, protect abortion service providers and aid public housing.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at some of the major bills approved by the State Legislature in an end-of-the-session flurry. And we’ll see why Harvey Weinstein, perhaps the original #MeToo abuser, will be staying in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: What is Great Paul? The story behind the iconic bell at St. Paul’s Cathedral.
description: The London cathedral’s bronze bell, weighing over 16 tons, is the largest bell ever cast in the British Isles.
content: LONDON — The history of Great Paul, the St. Paul’s Cathedral bell that was rung for a service commemorating Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee celebration on Friday, is one of toil and grandeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Fetterman discloses extent of heart issues: ‘I avoided going to the doctor.’
description: The Democratic candidate for Senate in Pennsylvania did not give a timeline for when he would return to the campaign trail.
content: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania, the Democratic nominee in what will be one of the hardest-fought Senate contests in the nation, has a heart condition called cardiomyopathy and appeared to have left other heart issues untreated for years, his doctor disclosed in a statement on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: One Island, Two Men and Lots of Big Questions
description: Karen Jennings talks about her new novel, “An Island,” and Phil Klay discusses “Uncertain Ground.”
content: Karen Jennings’s novel “An Island,” which was on the longlist for the Booker Prize in 2021, is set on a fictional unnamed island off the coast of Africa, where a man named Samuel has worked as a lighthouse keeper for more than 20 years. When a refugee washes up on shore one day, barely alive, Samuel navigates life around this stranger and flashes back to his own past, including his role in a political uprising and years that he spent in prison. On this week’s podcast, Jennings says that the book’s somewhat fable-like tone was very intentional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: A Conceptual ‘Queer’ Club at the Guggenheim
description: Perfume Genius performed at a benefit for young collectors.
content: New York’s hottest club is Guggenheim. It has everything: trans performers named after cocktails, live puppets, business executives and fashion plates who wear dresses made from human hair and act surprised when asked about their outfit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Bill Walker, Nashville Force as Conductor and Arranger, Dies at 95
description: He scored chart-topping records for country stars and later served as the musical director of “The Johnny Cash Show.”
content: NASHVILLE — Bill Walker, a conductor and arranger who became a musical force in Nashville, scoring popular recordings for country stars like Marty Robbins and Connie Smith and serving as musical director for Johnny Cash’s primetime television variety show, died on May 26 at a rehabilitation facility near here. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Russian and African leaders meet, one needing allies, the other grain.
description: A meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the head of the African Union, President Macky Sall of Senegal, showed that Africa is not prepared to cut ties to Russia.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — A meeting on Friday between the head of the African Union and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia highlighted the acute needs each one hopes the other can fill: Africa needs food, and the Kremlin needs allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Keeping Up With Crypto
description: David Yaffe-Bellany, who covers cryptocurrencies for The Times, talks about the crash of an industry that is firmly rooted in global culture.
content: In an ad campaign during the 2022 Super Bowl, the actor Matt Damon stands on a ship in outer space, looking out over a giant red planet. “Fortune favors the brave,” he says. Super Bowl ads can cost up to $7 million for 30 seconds; this one was for Crypto.com and championed those brave enough to invest in what was then a booming industry. Three months later, crypto came crashing down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Democrats Face Pressure on Crime From a New Front: Their Base
description: Not long ago, the party was focused on police reform, but rising fears of violence, especially among communities of color, have led candidates to change course.
content: BALTIMORE — A crowd of several hundred voters listened closely as Wes Moore, a Democratic candidate for governor of Maryland, unspooled a soaring peroration about bringing a spirit of unity to state government. Introduced by a sparkling drum line and a row of local dignitaries on a bright and windy Saturday, Mr. Moore promised to deliver a better quality of life for East Baltimore on issues from education to personal safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Sheryl Sandberg’s Long (Overdue) Goodbye
description: The Meta C.O.O. leaves a legacy of stunning financial success — and a company still in denial about its toxic impact.
content: When exactly is the right time to exit the limelight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: Will shifts in Australia and New Zealand lead to a ‘divorce’ from the monarchy?
description: The debate over whether to sever ties with Britain’s royal family has traditionally attracted little mainstream interest in the two members of the Commonwealth.
content: In some countries in the Commonwealth, the global group of former British colonies, the debate over whether to sever ties with Britain’s royal family has been fierce. In 2020, Barbados decided to remove the queen as its head of state and become a republic, and other Caribbean countries may follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Is ‘Greedflation’ Rewriting Economics, or Do Old Rules Still Apply?
description: Economists and politicians are debating whether monopolistic companies are fueling inflation in ways that confound longstanding theory.
content: There are few good things about living through a period with the highest inflation in four decades, but here’s one: It’s a chance to re-examine what happens in an economy that’s gone haywire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliot Schrefer
title: 2 Literary Novels Find the Poetry in Animal Rescue
description: A Nobel laureate and a future publisher play major roles in Margarita Engle’s “Singing With Elephants” and Michael Morpurgo’s “The Puffin Keeper.”
content: SINGING WITH ELEPHANTSBy Margarita Engle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Cobalt Blue Is Color Rushing Our Summer
description: “With so much turmoil in the world right now, it’s important to bring joy to life’s moments.”
content: Your eyes aren’t deceiving you: You are, in fact, seeing cobalt blue everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Carbon Dioxide Levels Are Highest in Human History
description: Humans pumped 36 billion tons of the planet-warming gas into the atmosphere in 2021, more than in any previous year. It comes from burning oil, gas and coal.
content: The amount of planet-warming carbon dioxide in the atmosphere broke a record in May, continuing its relentless climb, scientists said Friday. It is now 50 percent higher than the preindustrial average, before humans began the widespread burning of oil, gas and coal in the late 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Reihan Salam
description: A conversation with Reihan Salam.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Reihan Salam. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Grow a Garden in a Small Space
description: With a few containers, some good soil and plenty of sunlight, you can grow flowers, vegetables and more just about anywhere.
content: Running the length of my driveway is a slender strip of lawn, barely three feet wide. Blessed with full sun, the grass and weeds grow fast, and because the space is so narrow and blocked in by my neighbor’s fence, it’s miserable to mow. So, two years ago, I lined up a row of raised beds along it and turned the unremarkable plot into a luscious garden where this year I am growing tomatoes, eggplant, Swiss chard, pole beans and cucumbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How Ordering a Pint of Guinness Might Explain Economics
description: Boris Johnson’s proposal to bring back the imperial system is a reflection of “path dependence.”
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s push to give renewed prominence to the old imperial system of weights and measures in the United Kingdom is stirring fresh interest in a fascinating corner of economics: path dependence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: When Your Colleagues’ Mental Health Is on the Agenda
description: A general awareness of how people are coping is one thing. Sharing specific personal details crosses a line.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harry First and Darren Bush
title: The U.S. Can Take On the Oil Cartel That Enables Putin, and Win
description: Congress should allow the Justice Department to sue OPEC for violating antitrust laws.
content: For more than two decades, Congress has been considering a bill that would allow the Justice Department to sue OPEC members for violating antitrust law by colluding to control the supply and price of oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Pennsylvania court sides with McCormick for now, ordering undated ballots to be counted.
description: David McCormick, who was trailing Dr. Mehmet Oz by fewer than 1,000 votes, had sued to have ballots without handwritten dates on their return envelopes counted.
content: Update: David McCormick conceded the exceedingly close race for the Republican nomination for Senate in Pennsylvania on Friday to Dr. Mehmet Oz. Read the news story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadians still admire the queen, but most want to see the monarchy come to an end.
description: In a recent poll, 67 percent of respondents said they opposed the idea of Charles succeeding his mother to become Canada’s king.
content: OTTAWA — When Queen Elizabeth II of Britain first took the throne, symbols of the crown and royal coat of arms appeared seemingly everywhere in Canada, which remains part of the Commonwealth, including on mundane objects like mailboxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Phillies Fire Their Manager, but Their Flaws Run Deeper
description: Philadelphia’s expensive roster has underperformed — to put it mildly. The team hopes a “different voice” is the answer after dismissing Joe Girardi.
content: For Philadelphia fans disappointed by the 76ers, who followed years of N.B.A. failure with only muted success, the Phillies have a message: Hold my Yuengling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Builds a Laser Weapon to Zap Threats Out of the Sky
description: From science fiction to facts in the air: Israel says a prototype downed rockets and drones in recent tests.
content: JERUSALEM — After two decades of research and experimentation, Israeli defense officials now say they have a working prototype of a high-powered laser gun that can intercept rockets, mortar shells, drones and anti-tank missiles in flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Douglas Morino
title: Woman Testifies That Bill Cosby Kissed Her When She Was 14
description: She testified at a civil trial in Los Angeles brought by another woman accusing Mr. Cosby of sexual assault. A spokesman for Mr. Cosby denied all the accusations against him.
content: Kimberly Burr testified Friday that she was 14 years old when Bill Cosby invited her into his trailer on a film set in Los Angeles in 1975 and started kissing her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Fossil-Fuel Shares Lead the Stock Market. How Awkward.
description: If you want to make money in the market but also be a responsible citizen in a warming world, you’re in a tough spot. But there are some promising options, our columnist says.
content: It is no secret that the stock market has been rocky since the start of the year. Tech giants like Apple, Microsoft, Google and Amazon have been no help at all. Their shares have all had double-digit percentage declines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Covid vaccine misinformation still fuels fears surrounding pregnancy, a new study finds.
description: Health experts, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated against the coronavirus as soon as possible, to protect both maternal and fetal health.
content: A steady bombardment of coronavirus misinformation during the pandemic has left nearly one-third of American women who are pregnant, or who plan to become pregnant, believing at least one falsehood about coronavirus vaccinations and pregnancy, according to a new study. A higher share were unsure whether to believe the myths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in June
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Alex Traub
title: Escaped Texas Killer Dies in Shootout With Police, Officials Say
description: Gonzalo Artemio Lopez, who escaped from a prison bus last month, was a prime suspect in the killings of  four students and their grandfather, at a home on Thursday, the authorities said.
content: One of the most dramatic manhunts in Texas history ended late Thursday when a convicted murderer who had escaped from a prison bus last month was killed in a shootout with the police, hours after he became the prime suspect in the killing of five people at a home, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the Editorial Board
title: Who Killed Journalist Shireen Abu Akleh?
description: An independent investigation is needed to determine who shot Ms. Abu Akleh and to establish whether she was a target because of her work.
content: In her 25 years as a journalist for Al Jazeera, Shireen Abu Akleh covered many clashes between Israelis and Palestinians. So when she went to the occupied West Bank city of Jenin in the early morning of May 11 to cover an Israeli Army operation in a refugee camp, she took all the requisite precautions. She wore a helmet and blue body armor marked “press” in large letters. She stood near the entrance to the refugee camp with a group of other journalists, and her presence was immediately noticed. She was so well known among Arabic-speaking audiences that a crowd gathered to watch her work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Voters Say They Want Gun Control. Their Votes Say Something Different.
description: Broad public support on the issue may not be as broad as polling shows or as Democrats hope.
content: It’s one of the most puzzling questions for Democrats in American politics: Why is the political system so unresponsive to gun violence? Expanded background checks routinely receive more than 80 percent or 90 percent support in polling. Yet gun control legislation usually gets stymied in Washington and Republicans never seem to pay a political price for their opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Angel Olsen Finds a New Gear in a Vintage Genre: Country
description: “Big Time,” an album made at a tumultuous time in the singer-songwriter’s life, is charged with cleareyed emotion and heartbreaking moments.
content: Angel Olsen does not care for empty pleasantries, in conversation or her music. “I don’t like small talk,” the 35-year-old St. Louis-born singer and songwriter said in a recent New Yorker profile, while driving around Asheville, N.C., the town she has called home for nearly a decade. Similarly, the songs on her superb sixth album, “Big Time,” prefer plunging right into the depths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: In the wake of Black Lives Matter, the Caribbean reassesses the British crown.
description: Public sentiment toward the monarchy has soured in the region, and calls for reparations for Britain’s often brutal role in the slave trade have been rising.
content: Of all the places where Queen Elizabeth II remains head of state, the future of the monarchy looks bleakest among the nations of the Caribbean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Nadal Reaches French Open Final on Zverev’s Abrupt Injury
description: Rafael Nadal and Alexander Zverev had taken more than three hours to get toward the end of a second set. Then Zverev twisted his right ankle and had to stop.
content: PARIS — Sweat dripping off their faces as the grueling rallies piled up, Rafael Nadal and Alexander Zverev played for more than three hours in the Paris humidity and appeared set, whether they liked it or not, to play for hours more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In the choreography of royal events, Harry and Meghan’s presence is notable.
description: The appearance by Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, at St. Paul’s Cathedral on Friday was their first official royal outing since early 2020.
content: LONDON — The most eagerly anticipated guests at Friday’s thanksgiving service arrived well before the senior members of the royal family. Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, walked into St. Paul’s Cathedral shortly after 11 a.m., turning every head in the vaulting nave as the couple walked, hand in hand, to their seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Douglas Morino
title: Witness for Bill Cosby Accuser Says Sex Assault Memories Not Eroded by Time
description: The expert on memory was called to testify at a civil trial brought by Judy Huth, who is suing Mr. Cosby on grounds that he assaulted her decades ago.
content: The impact of sexual assault on memory became the focus Thursday of the civil trial in Los Angeles where Bill Cosby has been sued by a woman, Judy Huth, who says he sexually assaulted her when she was a teenager, some 47 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a Kafkaesque Tamil head trip, an Argentine queer drama, a Rwandan girls-school thriller and more.
content: Trying to summarize or describe this spectacularly zany Tamil mindboggler is a fool’s errand, but I’ll make an attempt: Saravanan (Kalaiyarasan), a young bank employee who also calls himself Freud, wakes up in his apartment in Chennai, in South India, and realizes he has suddenly grown the tail of a horse. Dazed and confused, he wanders around the city avoiding curious stares and trying to seek answers from a “dream interpreter,” a mad mathematician, an astrologer and others. At some point the setting switches to a bucolic village adorned with portraits of the bygone Tamil megastar MGR; at another, the story turns into a murder investigation that draws on Western theorists like Jacques Lacan. Amid all this, Kalaiyarasan walks around with a perpetually confounded face and a pitch-perfect horsetail twitch, and the directors Manoj Leonel Jason and Shyam Sunder play around with psychedelic lights, crazy Dutch angles and dialogue stuffed with riddles and jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘… What the End Will Be’ Review: Learning to Let Go
description: The intergenerational comedy is a poignant reflection on sexuality, mortality and Black masculinity by the playwright Mansa Ra.
content: Kinship with our elders is a privilege not often afforded to queer people. How many sons have come out to gay fathers and grandfathers? Imagining the possibility of these generational bonds feels like a reparative gesture in “…What the End Will Be,” an astute and poignant reflection on sexuality, mortality and Black masculinity by the playwright Mansa Ra, which opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Man Breaks Into Dallas Museum of Art and Damages Ancient Greek Artifacts
description: Brian Hernandez, 21, is accused of smashing a door with a steel chair and damaging items with an estimated value of $1 million or more, museum officials said.
content: A man smashed his way into the Dallas Museum of Art and damaged three ancient Greek artifacts dating to the 5th and 6th centuries B.C., museum officials said on Thursday.

title: Tennis Tops Women’s Sports, and Yet Still Fights for Footing

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: California’s water wasters
description: One district has gotten tough with residents who repeatedly flout the rules: Their taps have been slowed to trickle.
content: CALABASAS, California — Tucked into the Santa Monica Mountains, the average home here goes for around $1.8 million, the gardens are bursting with pansies fit for rainy England, and hefty fines have done little to restrain many homeowners from squandering water in a time of drought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The St. Paul’s event is a welcome break from political pressure for Boris Johnson.
description: His attendance at the service of thanksgiving during the Platinum Jubilee celebrations for Queen Elizabeth II is also an opportunity to stride the global stage and rub shoulders with royalty.
content: LONDON — When Boris Johnson, Britain’s embattled prime minister, gave a reading from the New Testament at a service in St. Paul’s Cathedral during Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations on Friday, it was a chance for him to step back from domestic political pressures, stride the global stage and rub shoulders with royalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: How Greg Abbott and Under 4 Percent of Texans Are Ruining the State for the Rest of Us
description: What about the millions of us in the state who are not hard-right Republicans?
content: HOUSTON — Greg Abbott probably thought he was doing the right thing when he skipped out on the N.R.A. convention last week and headed to Uvalde to play the part of a concerned Texas governor. Maybe something showed up in instant polls suggesting that he — and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and Senator John Cornyn — avoid the pro-gun crowd just this once. Maybe it was the banner over the George R. Brown Convention Center that promised “14 Acres of Guns & Gear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Comey
title: Not Every Breakup Is About Being Broken
description: She was everything I needed — until, with her love, my needs changed.
content: I was dying the morning I met Sarah. I ordered a latte from the campus coffee shop because she had done the same. To make up for it, I starved myself until late that night. Luckily, it had been made with skim milk, not whole, so I was allowed to have dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Alyce McFadden
title: Is Jan. 6 a Winning Political Issue? We’re About to Find Out.
description: Democratic candidates have shied away from talking about the Capitol siege. That could change if voters flock to a former federal prosecutor running for a House seat in California.
content: On Tuesday, we’ll get an unusually clear test of the political power of Jan. 6 at the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Antony Starr Contends With Accountability, Onscreen and Off
description: Starr, who plays the cruel superhero Homelander on the Amazon Prime Video series “The Boys,” returns to TV after his conviction in an assault in Spain earlier this year.
content: One lesson taught repeatedly by “The Boys,” the superhero series on Amazon Prime Video, is the danger of celebrity: Do not be too worshipful of any public figures, it warns, because you never really know what they’re like behind the scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Opera’s ‘Island of Misfit Toys’ Takes Its Biggest Stage Yet
description: The American Modern Opera Company, a collective of restless and enterprising young musicians and dancers, is preparing for the Ojai Music Festival.
content: CATSKILL, N.Y. — At the Lumberyard center here on a recent evening, more than 15 artists gathered outdoors around a long banquet spread over several picnic tables that had been lined up and topped with tea lights, bottles of rosé and accouterments for a feast of roasted pork lettuce wraps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Jesse McKinley
title: N.Y. Republican Drops Re-Election Bid After Bucking His Party on Guns
description: Representative Chris Jacobs, whose district includes Buffalo suburbs, abandoned his campaign after his support for a federal assault weapons ban caused a G.O.P. backlash.
content: In the wake of deadly mass shootings in Buffalo and Uvalde, Texas, Representative Chris Jacobs of New York, a congressman serving his first full term in the House, stunned fellow Republicans by embracing a federal assault weapons ban and limits on high-capacity magazines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coralie Kraft
title: ‘P-Valley’: How Katori Hall Made a Progressive Show About Strippers
description: Based on Hall’s 2015 play about a Southern strip club, her Starz series treats dancers as complex human beings, not set dressing.
content: Unlike other television shows in which a dramatic scene might take place in a strip club with anonymous women twisting in the background — props, basically — Katori Hall’s “P-Valley” focuses on the dancers themselves. Who knew they could be more than just decoration?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Unpacking ‘The Secret Life of Secrets’
description: In a new book, Michael Slepian considers the costs of keeping quiet.
content: Michael Slepian had just finished presenting the results of his research on secrets at Columbia University when he glanced at his phone and realized he’d missed two calls from his father.
